Notable Contributions: Led first major Puritan migration in 1630 and served 12 terms as governor; preached the "city upon a hill" vision that shaped New England's identity​:contentReference[oaicite:68]{index=68}​:contentReference[oaicite:69]{index=69}

Role/Occupation: Pilgrim leader, Governor of Plymouth Colony, historian
Notable Contributions: Signatory of the Mayflower Compact and long-time Plymouth governor (over 30 years); authored "Of Plymouth Plantation," the seminal history of the colony​:contentReference[oaicite:70]{index=70}

Role/Occupation: Minister, theologian, founder of Rhode Island
Notable Contributions: Advocated separation of church and state and religious liberty; banished from Massachusetts Bay and founded Providence Plantations (Rhode Island) in 1636 as a refuge of toleration​:contentReference[oaicite:71]{index=71}​:contentReference[oaicite:72]{index=72}

Role/Occupation: Midwife and religious dissenter in Massachusetts Bay
Notable Contributions: Central figure in the 1636–38 Antinomian Controversy, she challenged Puritan clergy on matters of faith and was tried and banished from Massachusetts​:contentReference[oaicite:73]{index=73}; helped found Portsmouth in Rhode Island, symbolizing early religious freedom and women's influence​:contentReference[oaicite:74]{index=74}

Last non-military Royal Governor of Massachusetts (1771–74) whose strict enforcement of British laws (e.g. Stamp Act) exacerbated colonial unrest​:contentReference[oaicite:75]{index=75}; an important Loyalist historian who documented Massachusetts Bay’s history

Role/Occupation: Statesman, lawyer (Massachusetts), Founding Father of the U.S.
Notable Contributions: Leader in the Continental Congress and advocate for independence; helped draft and vigorously defended the Declaration of Independence​:contentReference[oaicite:76]{index=76}; later first U.S. Vice President and second President​:contentReference[oaicite:77]{index=77}. In Massachusetts, remembered for defending British soldiers after the Boston Massacre and shaping revolutionary policy​:contentReference[oaicite:78]{index=78}

Role/Occupation: Political agitator, Patriot leader, Governor of Massachusetts
Notable Contributions: Organized colonial resistance to British taxes—founder of the Sons of Liberty and architect of the Boston Tea Party; delegate to Continental Congress, signer of the Declaration of Independence​:contentReference[oaicite:79]{index=79}; served as Massachusetts Governor (1790s) and influenced the development of American republican ideals​:contentReference[oaicite:80]{index=80}

Role/Occupation: Merchant, President of Continental Congress, Massachusetts Governor
Notable Contributions: Prominent Patriot financier of the American Revolution—used his wealth and influence to support the colonial cause​:contentReference[oaicite:81]{index=81}; presided over the Second Continental Congress and was first to sign the Declaration of Independence (with his famous large signature)​:contentReference[oaicite:82]{index=82}; as Massachusetts’ first post-independence Governor, pushed for ratification of the U.S. Constitution​:contentReference[oaicite:83]{index=83}

Role/Occupation: Lawyer and legislator in colonial Massachusetts
Notable Contributions: Articulated early American opposition to British tyranny – his 1761 speech against Writs of Assistance ("Taxation without representation is tyranny") was seminal in the revolutionary movement. A member of the Massachusetts Assembly, he inspired colonial unity and rights in the 1760s

Most prominent New England clergyman of the late 17th–early 18th century​:contentReference[oaicite:84]{index=84}; prolific writer of sermons and tracts, defender of Puritan orthodoxy (involved in Salem witch trials) yet also a pioneer in promoting smallpox inoculation based on new scientific ideas​:contentReference[oaicite:85]{index=85}

As the Pilgrims’ military advisor, he organized the colony’s defense and led preemptive strikes against threats​:contentReference[oaicite:86]{index=86}; his leadership in the colony’s early years (including 1621 encounters and the 1623 Wessagusset affair) helped ensure Plymouth’s survival. Later founded and settled Duxbury, MA

Birth: c.1590, near present-day Bristol, Rhode Island
Role/Occupation: Grand Sachem of the Wampanoag Confederacy
Notable Contributions: Formed a peace alliance with the Plymouth colonists in 1621 and upheld it for four decades​:contentReference[oaicite:87]{index=87}​:contentReference[oaicite:88]{index=88}; shared critical agricultural knowledge that enabled the Pilgrims’ survival​:contentReference[oaicite:89]{index=89}. His diplomacy created a rare period of coexistence between Native people and English settlers until his death

Led a coalition of New England tribes in King Philip’s War (1675–1676), the region’s greatest indigenous uprising against colonists​:contentReference[oaicite:90]{index=90}. Though ultimately defeated and killed, Metacomet’s war inflicted heavy losses and is remembered as a pivotal conflict in New England’s colonial history​:contentReference[oaicite:91]{index=91}

Revolutionary War officer famed for courage at Bunker Hill in 1775 (helped command colonial forces)​:contentReference[oaicite:92]{index=92}; earlier, earned a frontier folk-hero reputation in the French & Indian War. Though bold in battle, he struggled with complex campaigns and was semi-retired after 1777​:contentReference[oaicite:93]{index=93}

Co-led (with Benedict Arnold) the dawn raid to capture Fort Ticonderoga in May 1775, securing valuable artillery for the Patriots​:contentReference[oaicite:94]{index=94}; leader of the Green Mountain Boys militia defending Vermont’s autonomy. Advocated for Vermont’s eventual statehood, becoming an icon of Vermont’s independence

Role/Occupation: General in Revolutionary War (Continental Army and later British Army)
Notable Contributions: Early American war hero (commanded victories at Ticonderoga and Saratoga) who infamously betrayed the Patriot cause​:contentReference[oaicite:95]{index=95}; in 1780, attempted to hand over West Point to the British in exchange for money and rank​:contentReference[oaicite:96]{index=96}. His name has become synonymous with “traitor” in American history

Washington’s ablest general and strategist of the Southern Campaign (1780–1781)​:contentReference[oaicite:97]{index=97}; Greene’s leadership in the Carolinas, marked by a strategy of attrition (despite few outright wins), forced the British to retreat from the interior South. His success in regaining the Carolinas and Georgia made him one of the Revolution’s greatest heroes

Role/Occupation: General, Chief of Artillery in Continental Army
Notable Contributions: Oversaw the transport of captured Fort Ticonderoga cannons to Boston in winter 1776, enabling the Patriots to drive out British forces; commanded Continental artillery in major battles (Trenton, Monmouth, Yorktown). After the war, served as the first U.S. Secretary of War, shaping American military policy

Role/Occupation: Silversmith, courier for Patriot movement (American Revolution)
Notable Contributions: His "Midnight Ride" on April 18, 1775 warned Massachusetts militia of the approaching British troops before Lexington & Concord​:contentReference[oaicite:98]{index=98}, an act that made him an American folk hero. Also a master engraver and early industrialist; post-war, he opened one of America’s first copper foundries. Revere’s life bridged artisan craft and the patriot cause

President of the Massachusetts Provincial Congress in 1775; dispatched riders Paul Revere and William Dawes to alert Lexington. Volunteered at the Battle of Bunker Hill and was killed in action, becoming a martyr for the Revolution. Warren’s death rallied the Patriot cause; he was eulogized as a symbol of sacrifice

Introduced formal Palladian architecture to America​:contentReference[oaicite:99]{index=99}; designed landmark New England structures, including Newport’s Touro Synagogue (1763) and Redwood Library (1750) and Boston’s King’s Chapel (1754)​:contentReference[oaicite:100]{index=100}. Credited as America’s first professionally trained architect, he set a high aesthetic standard in the colonial era

Widely regarded as the first American-born professional architect​:contentReference[oaicite:101]{index=101}. As Boston’s leading architect of the early republic, Bulfinch designed the Massachusetts State House (opened 1798) and helped plan Boston’s transition from a colonial town to a modern city​:contentReference[oaicite:102]{index=102}. He later contributed to the design of the U.S. Capitol. Bulfinch’s works introduced refined Neoclassical (Federal) style to New England​:contentReference[oaicite:103]{index=103}

Supervised construction of the Middlesex Canal (1790s), a 27-mile canal linking the Merrimack River to Boston—one of the first large-scale engineering projects in the U.S.​:contentReference[oaicite:104]{index=104}. Known as an early American civil engineer (sometimes called “Father of American Civil Engineering”)​:contentReference[oaicite:105]{index=105}, Baldwin also served in the Continental Army and introduced the Baldwin apple

Founded the American cotton textile industry by bringing British industrial know-how to New England. In 1793 he built Slater Mill in Pawtucket, RI – the first successful water-powered cotton-spinning mill in America​:contentReference[oaicite:106]{index=106}. Called the "Father of the American Industrial Revolution," Slater’s factory system launched New England’s transition to industrial economy​:contentReference[oaicite:107]{index=107}

Invented the **cotton gin** in 1793, a device that dramatically sped up cotton processing and revolutionized Southern agriculture​:contentReference[oaicite:108]{index=108}. Pioneered the concept of interchangeable parts in manufacturing firearms (proposed in 1797), laying the foundation for mass production in American industry​:contentReference[oaicite:109]{index=109}​:contentReference[oaicite:110]{index=110}. Often hailed as "the father of American technology" for his contributions

Her 1650 poetry collection *The Tenth Muse* was the first book of poetry by an American colonist, earning her recognition as the first accomplished New World poet​:contentReference[oaicite:111]{index=111}. Bradstreet’s writings, reflecting Puritan faith and personal experience, opened the door for American literature and especially women writers in New England

First African American woman to publish a book of poems (her 1773 volume *Poems on Various Subjects* )​:contentReference[oaicite:112]{index=112}. Brought to Boston as a slave, Wheatley became a literary prodigy, corresponded with George Washington, and used classical style to subtly critique slavery. Her achievement challenged contemporary views on race and intellect​:contentReference[oaicite:113]{index=113}

Authored influential patriotic plays, poems, and essays during the Revolutionary era, attacking British rule and advocating independence​:contentReference[oaicite:114]{index=114}. An Anti-Federalist voice after the war, she published *Observations on the new Constitution* (1788) under a pseudonym opposing ratification without a Bill of Rights​:contentReference[oaicite:115]{index=115}. In 1805, she wrote a pioneering three-volume *History of the American Revolution*​:contentReference[oaicite:116]{index=116}, making her one of America’s first female historians

Leader of the First Great Awakening (1740s) in New England; his sermons (notably “Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God”) sparked religious fervor and revivals in Massachusetts and Connecticut. Edwards combined deep Calvinist theology with vivid preaching, and is considered one of early America’s most important religious thinkers

A leading clergyman of New England who served as President of Harvard College (1685–1701) and influenced colonial policy. He helped negotiate the new Massachusetts charter in 1692 and urged restraint during the Salem witch trials. Increase Mather’s writings and sermons defended Puritan orthodoxy while occasionally advocating moderate reform

After a 1776 illness, Wilkinson claimed a genderless spiritual identity (“Public Universal Friend”) and led an itinerant ministry. Preached throughout New England and founded a religious community in western New York. As one of the first native-born American religious leaders, Wilkinson advocated pacifism, abolitionism, and celibacy, foreshadowing later utopian movements
